title: What's more balanced?
body:
1) A champion who wins 100% of the time in 50% of games (losing the other 50%).
2) A champion who wins 50% of the time in 100% of games.

I'll clarify why this is game theory and not the law of large numbers.

Game theory predicts the best choice based on multiple intelligent beings making decisions based on information. 

In league you are picking your champion based on information prior to the game (Enemy and allied champions). 

So a champion who wins 50% of all games, and a champion who wins 100% of games given a specific condition, a condition which occurs 50% of the time. Are two very different things.

I mean, there isn't really even a "right" or "wrong" answer to this question anyway, but only because we play in teams of 5 champions, not 1. The objectively best option would be to pick champions with a 50% win rate 100% of the time, in the first few picks, then pick champions who have a higher chance to win based on the information which has been gained by seeing the first 5 champions. 

There is a little bit more famous example in baseball, where you don't want a line up of 4 home run hitters. It's more advantageous to have 3 non-home run hitters (who more consistently get hits), and then the 4th batter be one who more consistently gets a home run, but less consistently gets a hit.

If: X = consistency, Y = Chance to win
For 1) X=1.00, Y=.50
Then: XY = 1.00 x .50 = .50

For 2) X=.50, Y=1.00
Then: XY = .50 x 1.00 = .50

Therefore: XY=XY

TLDR: Both clauses are equivalent

Yes, that's how blind math works. However this isn't about blind math. 
This is decisions being made by intellects in a system. 

It's not a statistical problem it's a game problem.

This would be a valid discussion in a 1v1 game, this game has too many variables to assume winning 50% and losing 50% guaranteed. You can heavily counter someone in this and get fed yet still lose because of the other variables. You whole idea here doesn't for this particular game.

Either way if I had to choose I would rather always have a 50% chance to win any game rather than being a guaranteed 50% winrate. I trust myself to be better than 50%.

The difference is actually to do with game theory. 
It's about making an informed decision vs a blind one. 

In a game of 5v5 draft both types have their place, as half of the picks (the last 2 for the first pick team and the last 3 for the second pick team) are making informed decisions. Where as the first 3 or 5 picks are pretty much blind.

If you pick a champion who has a 100% win rate in 50% of games, given conditions which, in a completely blind pick, would occur 50% of the time, the enemy can avoid those conditions and ensure you lose.

Now obviously the rates are exaggerated for emphasis.
